questions.question: What does UI stand for?
questions.correctAnswer: User Interface

questions.question: Which tool is primarily used for interface design and prototyping?
questions.correctAnswer: Figma

questions.question: What is vital for good accessibility?
questions.correctAnswer: High contrast

questions.question: What is a 'Wireframe'?
options: A low-fidelity visual guide that represents the skeletal framework
questions.correctAnswer: A low-fidelity visual guide that represents the skeletal framework

questions.question: What is the 'Golden Ratio' used for?
questions.correctAnswer: To create aesthetically pleasing proportions

questions.question: Which color space is primarily used for digital screens?
questions.correctAnswer: RGB

questions.question: What is 'White Space'?
options: The empty space between design elements
questions.correctAnswer: The empty space between design elements

questions.question: What is 'Kerning'?
options: Adjusting the spacing between individual characters
questions.correctAnswer: Adjusting the spacing between individual characters

questions.question: What is a 'User Persona'?
options: A fictional character representing a user type
questions.correctAnswer: A fictional character representing a user type

questions.question: What is 'Responsive Design'?
options: Design that adapts to different screen sizes
questions.correctAnswer: Design that adapts to different screen sizes

questions.question: What is 'Information Architecture'?
questions.correctAnswer: Structuring and organizing content effectively

questions.question: What is the difference between Serif and Sans Serif fonts?
options: Serifs have small strokes at the ends of letters, Sans Serifs do not
questions.correctAnswer: Serifs have small strokes at the ends of letters, Sans Serifs do not

questions.question: What is 'Affordance' in design?
options: Clues about how an object should be used (e.g., a button looking clickable)
questions.correctAnswer: Clues about how an object should be used (e.g., a button looking clickable)

questions.question: What is 'A/B Testing'?
options: Comparing two versions of a design to see which performs better
questions.correctAnswer: Comparing two versions of a design to see which performs better

questions.question: What is a 'User Journey Map'?
options: A visualization of the process a user goes through to accomplish a goal
questions.correctAnswer: A visualization of the process a user goes through to accomplish a goal

questions.question: What is 'Heuristic Evaluation'?
options: Evaluating a user interface against a set of usability principles
questions.correctAnswer: Evaluating a user interface against a set of usability principles

questions.question: What is the 'Rule of Thirds'?
options: Dividing an image into nine equal parts to create balanced compositions
questions.correctAnswer: Dividing an image into nine equal parts to create balanced compositions

questions.question: What is 'Microcopy'?
options: Small bits of text that guide users (e.g., error messages, button labels)
questions.correctAnswer: Small bits of text that guide users (e.g., error messages, button labels)

questions.question: What is 'Cognitive Load'?
options: The amount of mental effort required to use an interface
questions.correctAnswer: The amount of mental effort required to use an interface

questions.question: What is 'Mobile First' design?
options: Designing for mobile screens before larger screens
questions.correctAnswer: Designing for mobile screens before larger screens

questions.question: What is a 'Breadcrumb'?
options: A secondary navigation scheme that reveals users' location
questions.correctAnswer: A secondary navigation scheme that reveals users' location

questions.question: What is 'Card Sorting'?
options: A method used to help design or evaluate the information architecture
questions.correctAnswer: A method used to help design or evaluate the information architecture

questions.question: What is 'Fitts's Law'?
options: Time to acquire a target is a function of the distance to and size of the target
questions.correctAnswer: Time to acquire a target is a function of the distance to and size of the target

questions.question: What is 'Color Theory'?
options: The science and art of using color
questions.correctAnswer: The science and art of using color

questions.question: What is 'Leading' in typography?
options: The vertical space between lines of text
questions.correctAnswer: The vertical space between lines of text

questions.question: What is 'Hick's Law'?
options: The time it takes to make a decision increases with the number and complexity of choices
questions.correctAnswer: The time it takes to make a decision increases with the number and complexity of choices

questions.question: What is 'Gestalt Principles'?
options: Principles describing how humans group similar elements, cherish patterns and simplify complex images
questions.correctAnswer: Principles describing how humans group similar elements, cherish patterns and simplify complex images

questions.question: What is 'Skeuomorphism'?
options: Design concept of making items represented resemble their real-world counterparts
questions.correctAnswer: Design concept of making items represented resemble their real-world counterparts

questions.question: What is 'Accessibility (a11y)' concerned with?
options: Making websites usable by people of all abilities and disabilities
questions.correctAnswer: Making websites usable by people of all abilities and disabilities

questions.question: What is 'Progressive Disclosure'?
options: Maintaining the focus of a user's attention by reducing clutter, confusion, and cognitive workload
questions.correctAnswer: Maintaining the focus of a user's attention by reducing clutter, confusion, and cognitive workload

questions.question: What is 'Designing for the Fold' status today?
options: Still relevant but users are used to scrolling; content above fold is for engagement
questions.correctAnswer: Still relevant but users are used to scrolling; content above fold is for engagement

questions.question: What is the 'Von Restorff Effect'?
options: Also known as The Isolation Effect, predicts that when multiple similar objects are present, the one that differs from the rest is most likely to be remembered
questions.correctAnswer: Also known as The Isolation Effect, predicts that when multiple similar objects are present, the one that differs from the rest is most likely to be remembered

questions.question: What is 'Dark Pattern'?
options: A user interface that has been carefully crafted to trick users into doing things
questions.correctAnswer: A user interface that has been carefully crafted to trick users into doing things

questions.question: What is 'Gamification' in UX?
options: Applying game-design elements and game principles in non-game contexts
questions.correctAnswer: Applying game-design elements and game principles in non-game contexts

questions.question: What is 'Grid System'?
options: A structure (usually two-dimensional) made up of a series of intersecting straight (vertical, horizontal) lines used to structure content
questions.correctAnswer: A structure (usually two-dimensional) made up of a series of intersecting straight (vertical, horizontal) lines used to structure content

questions.question: What is 'Atomic Design'?
options: A methodology for creating design systems (Atoms, Molecules, Organisms, Templates, Pages)
questions.correctAnswer: A methodology for creating design systems (Atoms, Molecules, Organisms, Templates, Pages)

questions.question: What is 'Material Design'?
options: A design language developed by Google
questions.correctAnswer: A design language developed by Google

questions.question: What is 'Flat Design'?
options: A style of interface design emphasizing minimum use of stylistic elements that give the illusion of three dimensions
questions.correctAnswer: A style of interface design emphasizing minimum use of stylistic elements that give the illusion of three dimensions

questions.question: What is 'Double Diamond' process?
questions.correctAnswer: Discover, Define, Develop, Deliver

questions.question: What is 'Eye Tracking' used for?
options: To measure where the user is looking
questions.correctAnswer: To measure where the user is looking
